titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Wrote and read a little in the forenoon. Constant dread of visitors.— Dined and spent the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. He is unwell, as are some others of the family.

lg.l: “Canst thou not Minister to a mind diseas’d.”

div.p: Day. Rise between 9 and 10. Spend about an hour in dressing. It is one of the necessities of the time and the place. Breakfast. Read the Morning Chronicle for Opposition news, & the Times for the ministerial: This brings me to nearly twelve. Read or write about an hour. Then walk two more to pay a foolish visit, or two. from thence till 5. my dinner time read again or write. Generally dine at home or at Mr: Johnson’s. Am sure at least to pass the Evening & sup there; return home between 12 & 1. at night. look over the Courier smoke my segar, and just before 2 in the morning retire to bed.— What a life!

2. Visit this morning to Mr: Pinckney. Not at home. But I can expect no assistance from him to enable me to get away, and must therefore stay till I hear from Holland. My Patience must be drained to the very dregs.— As I was coming home met J. T. Sargent. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: Murdoch there. Return’d this day from Bath.— Find another cold coming on me.

3. Mr: Marshall called on me this morning. He is going to Holland, and enquired whether I should go soon. I know not what to answer.— Walk in the forenoon. Pass’d a couple of hours in the Poets’ Gallery, another collection of Paintings. The compound is singular, about half the subjects being taken from the Bible, and the other half from several of the british Poets. The former are the originals of the prints in Macklin’s Bible, now publishing.

The Room is not well adapted for an exhibition and half the pictures are lost by being placed in a bad light. But the proportion of good paintings appears to me greater than in either of the other galleries I have visited. Opie who has more here than any other Painter, gains upon my taste. His Henry and Emma is very good. There is an admirable scene of peasant girls, by Sir Joshua Reynolds, and a Woodman in Winter from Cowper’s task, also very excellent. (by Barker.).— On my return home found a line from Mr: Marshall, informing me of a vessel going to Amsterdam on Friday. He intends going in her, but I cannot.— Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Letter from my brother at the Hague of 17th last month, relieved me from great anxiety; but he has been very ill.

4. Visitors in abundance. Mr: Murdoch called and delivered me a letter from my brother at the Hague, dated the 28th: of last month. He mentions having sent me on the 22d: the supply, the want of which now detains me. But that letter being important of course I have not received it. I am almost become superstitious on this subject. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Walk after dinner with the young Ladies to Ludgate Hill. Evening according to custom.

5. Wrote a letter to my mother. Walk to the City. Mr: Wadsworth dined with me. Hall came in this afternoon: just return’d from Bath. We all went and passed the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s.— Mr: Rogers was here this morning, and yesterday. It seems the catastrophe at New-York, which I have long seen to be inevitable, has actually taken place.

6. Read New-York papers. Violent debates in congress. Dined at Mr: Pinckney’s. Mr: Church. Mr: Cutting, and a Mr: McPherson, whom I did not know. Mr: Pinckney says he thinks Tom Paine’s forte is irony. Q. N. Talk’d of his purity & independence of Spirit too. Pinckney is one of the school himself; and inclines to it in profession as much as he dares. Cutting said that the french manufactures were universally superior to the English excepting only hard ware. Church said the stocks of this Country were a circulating medium; I had said the contrary; and in the controversy Pinckney and Cutting both joined Church against me. The more I see of these people the more I find them destitute of information.— Home at about ten, and read a book of Pope’s Iliad. an employment more agreeable, and certainly much more instructive than that of discussing with the company I had quitted.

7. Sent a packet of newspapers to go by Mr: Marshall, to my brother. He had gone about an hour before. Another lesson upon delay. I have taken and forgotten enough. Went down to give Mr: R. Bird his letters for America. Did not see him & left my letters— (Packwood’s razor strops. N. 16. Grace-church street.) Lackington’s book shop. Finsbury Square. Home. Dined at Mr: Copley’s. Mr: Erving, Mr: & Mrs: Bromfield; and Captain Winslow. Had some little of the grace of consideration but not enough. Evening, (last part of it) at Mr: Johnson’s.
8. Hall was with me in the forenoon— Ride with the Ladies to the Park. Overtook him.— Walk interrupted by the rain. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Evening there too. Mr: Murdoch. Home at about 12.

9. Hall called on me between 12 & 1. We went to Mr: Johnson’s, from thence with Mr: Murdoch and the Ladies to the Exhibition. I persist in the opinion that Beechey’s portraits are much better than Hoppner’s. Walk’d back with the young Ladies. Hall left us. He goes this Evening to a ball at Highgate. Mrs: Court & her Daughters dined with us.— Evening but so so.— Music.— Conversation flagging.
10. Wrote and read a little. Short walk in the morning. At Mr: Johnson’s in the Evening. Play’d backgammon.— The usual asperities arose this Evening.— I must get away.

11. Hall here in the morning. Made our arrangements for the Evening. He called on me again after dinner with Rogers. It was late before we arrived at Mr: Johnson’s. From thence, went immediately with the Ladies to Ranelagh. More lessons of dress.— Dull and out of humour. After we arrived at Ranelagh, all my temper came out. too offensively perhaps. Latter part of the Evening however agreeable. The fantoccini are little better than a miserable puppet-show. The room was extremely thin of company. Between 12 and 1. we set off to return. Supp’d at Mr Johnson’s after our return. And at about half after three and in broad day-light, Hall left me at my lodgings.
12. Late up. Wrote a short letter to America. Dined and pass’d the Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. An Evening of satisfaction, and of explanation. Home at about 12.

13. Walk before dinner. Lounge at the exhibition Somerset House.— My Opinion of the portraits acquires additional confirmation, the more I see of them. Beechey’s are the best. Westall’s come next and Northcote, before Opie and Hoppner. The best miniatures are by Plimer.— Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Cards— Part of the family dull.—

14. Reading Gibbon’s memoirs of his life and writings. A very valuable piece of Biography. Dined with Murdoch.— Cutting said he wished Mr: Morris might be appointed to succeed Mr: Pinckney as American Minister here.— Mr: Sandi. Mr: Crewe. Mr: Lyle. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Music.— Murdoch gives too good Madeira.

15. I have undertaken as an amusement to read the Epic Poets (the foreigners in the English translations.) An hour every day is devoted to the purpose. Began Pope’s Homer on the 29th. of last month. I read one book a day. This is not perhaps the best possible way of employing my time. But it is better than lounging in the streets or doing absolutely nothing. As I now live I have only the choice of my dissipation.
Hall called on me. Would not go to dine at Mr: Johnson’s. Left him at the London Coffee-House.— Day from dinner time past as usual. Evening tolerably pleasant.

16. Visit from Mr Wadsworth— Called on Hall and Rogers who were out. On H. Sargent, the young Painter, who has considerable talent in that Line. He shew me his work-room with his paintings.— His likenesses to general are very good. He says it is a great question among the artists whether the style of finishing pictures, like those of Beechey, or of centering all the effect in the face, like Hoppner and Laurence is preferable. Rather inclines to the latter which was introduced and recommended by the practice of Sir Joshua Reynolds: but he thinks it is carried too far by some of the imitators, and for my own part I think that a very little of it is by much too much.— At Mr: Pinckney’s. Not at home. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s Hall, Russell, Murdoch there. Music. Cards but I did not play.— Good humoured.

17. Forenoon principally spent in my two adopted occupations.— Weather very fine. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. From thence went with the Ladies to Drury-Lane Theatre. Hall & Russell were to have come at 1/2 past 5 to take two of them. They had not arrived at 6. We therefore set off without them, but met them before we had run a quarter of a mile. We were in a great hurry. The performances were 6th: Night of a new Opera called Mahmoud or the Prince of Persia. and a Farce entirely new called Alive and Merry. The music of the first was a passport for its dulness. The last, a first attempt, was of doubtful success, and still more dubious merit. A new singer by the name of Braham, pleased us in the Opera. He is pronounced the finest tenor in the world, by those who here undertake to award such ranks, and has indeed a very good voice.— He was indeed the pretext of our going this day, and the Ladies are delighted with him.— We returned to supper at Mr: Johnson’s, and by the pleasures of the company were kept there till almost two in the morning.

18. Visit from Mr: Wadsworth, and returned it. Went with him and Mr: Deas to the exhibition at Somerset house. Met Hall there. Stroll’d round till near 5. My first judgments acquire daily new strength. They do not altogether accord with the fashionable taste. Dined alone. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Murdoch there. Play’d Whist malgré moi. Invited to the dance to-morrow Evening. Cannot go. Accounts from America very unpleasant, but to me by no means unexpected.— Affected as much as I could good humour. Succeeded no better than usual.

19. The difference between the popular and Executive branches of the American Government is approaching to a crisis, and I fear the superior force is not where it should be. Resolves of the house on the 17th: of last month, appear in this day’s papers.— Called to see Forbes, who is very unwell, but found him not at home. Met Mr: Johnson, & Hall successively. Talk’d unreasonably.— Dined alone. Evening at Covent Garden Theatre; saw The Way to get married, a new Comedy that has had a very great run this Season, and Harlequin’s treasure, a pantomime as stupid, as they always are.

20. Hall called on me this morning; offered to supply me with money, if I should have occasion. told him I would call on him if I should not before next week receive my long expected letter from my brother. Mr: Pinckney here too. Said he had now recd: bills from America, which would place our pecuniary concerns on rather a better footing here, than they have been.— Said he would enquire of Messrs: Bird &c to know if they could furnish me. He seems to think right on the American news. But he has a leaning in general towards the strongest side.— Has letters from Mr: Monroe. The french have
given up it is said their intention of sending an Envoy Extraordinary to America, to talk in high terms to our Executive.— The batteries are changed it seems.— Dined at Mr: Johnson’s Evening with the Ladies at Drury Lane Theatre. Saw Romeo and Juliet. Romeo by Barrymore. (For his benefit) Juliet Mrs: Jordan Mercutio by Dodd. The part of Juliet alone was well performed: all the rest were indifferent. Her action in the Garden Scene was not only superior to what I had ever seen of it, but almost to any conception I could form of it. In the more tragical scenes she was not superior, and sometimes not equal to Miss Wallis.— In the funeral procession the bed of state was not brought forward on the stage but kept at the extremity of the scene. I think this an improvement; at least in point of decorum.— The Nurse, by Mrs: Hopkins was very badly done indeed.— The farce was the Follies of a Day, cut down to three Acts, and of course much mutilated. The page by Mrs: Bland. Susan Miss Farren. Figaro. R. Palmer, and Almaviva Bannister junior. They all appear clumsy enough compared with the french actors of the same parts.— Mrs: Bland however sung very prettily.— Return’d immediately home, it being late.

21. At Sir Francis Baring’s this morning to deliver the order I received yesterday from my brother for at length it has arrived. But Sir Francis is gone into the Country for about ten days. Parliament was yesterday dissolved.— An hour at Lackington’s book shop, & bought some books. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: Ulett an English clergyman, Mr: Washington, and Mr Rawlin, Gentlemen from Virginia. Russell and Murdoch were the company. The two latter past the Evening, and supped likewise there. Received another letter from my brother enclosing some from America. Conversation between sweet and bitter, in the Evening.— When I came home found a line from Mr: Pinckney, informing me that Messrs: Bird, Savage & Bird, will furnish me the money for which I have occasion.

22. Forenoon engaged as usual. Called on Russell and Forbes. Latter has changed his lodgings. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. And the Evening. Mr Murdoch there, at the close of it. Fettered according to custom, as indeed we always must be.— Finished reading Popes Iliad, at the day; and am so dissipated as to think even this a sort of application.

23. To the London Coffee house, with Hall. Skinner’s vessel is gone. To Messrs: Bird &c. to get some money. It will be more convenient to them on Wednesday. Shall therefore go again. Went to Mr: Clagett’s to enquire for an opportunity to go to Rotterdam. heard of one at the close of this week. To see the Captain to-morrow. Visit to Forbes. found him very unwell, with a slow nervous fever. Dined at home alone. Went with Mr: Wadsworth’s to a Ball at Mr: Pinckney’ s. Danced almost all the Evening. Company principally unknown to me. Two daughters of Mrs: Siddons among them.— Party very pleasant. At home before 2 in the morning; That is very early.

24. To Mr: Clagett’s to see the Captain of the vessel going to Rotterdam. Found him there and went with him on board the vessel at Wapping Old stairs. It is a small Prussian
schooner with very indifferent accommodations, for which I am to pay a price of real extortion. But I am used to it. On my return called on Forbes.— Met Hall, Rogers & Mr: Stuart there. Forbes is somewhat better. Dined at Home. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s. Murdoch sent for. Evening not remarkable.

25. Sent my baggage on board the vessel. Went to Mr: Bird’s, and at length procured the money Sat to Mr Hull. Dined at Mr: Johnson’s. Mr: Hall, & Russell there, and Murdoch. Mrs: Johnson’s birth day. But little Music in the Evening. Russell is going to France in a day or two.

26. Preparing for my departure. Informed from my Captain that he sails early next week. Couple of hours with Mr: Hull. At Mr: Pinckney’s to ask for a Passport. received it accordingly. Visits to Mr: Copley, and Mr Hope. Dined at home. Then went to Mr: Johnson’s, and from thence with the Ladles to Merlin’s exhibition. It is hardly worth seeing a second time. Return’d to supper, and as usual home between 12. and 1.

27. Continuing preparations for my departure. At about 4. P.M. received word from the Captain that he should sail to-morrow morning at 5 o’clock—that the wind is perfectly fair and if it continues so he will be at Gravesend by noon, ready to proceed from thence. This intelligence comes quite unexpected, and precipitates me so as to make several arrangements I had proposed, quite impracticable. Went immediately to the Duke of Portland’s office to procure an order to permit my embarkation. Was obliged to return a second time, and then informed I could not have the order till ten or eleven to-morrow morning. Very anxious lest after all my disappointments I should lose this opportunity of returning to Holland. Evening at Mr: Johnson’s, an Evening of delight and of regret. Took my leave of all the family with sensations unusually painful. Conversation with Mr: Johnson.— At home at 2 in the morning.

28. Up at 6. and from that time till 12. obliged to crowd the business of several days, into so short a space. I had received from Messrs: Clagett and Pratt, yesterday evening two successive letters informing me that I must be at Gravesend by noon, and afterwards by 10 or 11 at latest.— It was impossible to go without the order to allow me to embark, which could not be procured till within five minutes before 12. I determined therefore to lose not one minute of unnecessary time and to run the risk which I could not prevent.— At a number of shops. At Hall’s and left several necessary matters with him. An hour at Mr: Hull’s. At the Duke of Portland’s office myself by 10. Nobody there. Sent Whitcomb again just before 12 and at length procured the necessary order. Stepped without the loss of a minute into a Post-Chaise, and just at 4. afternoon arrived at Gravesend 25 miles from Osborns’s Adelphi Hotel. The Verwagtend Fortuyn, Captain Heinke Garmers, the vessel in which I had engaged my passage, after waiting for me three or four hours had just got under way with a fine fresh breeze. the custom house officers and the inspector, upon observing in my Passport my official character were very civil in accommodating and facilitating my departure. I took a boat immediately to follow the vessel, and after some contrivance of the boatmen to practice and imposition to encrease their fare, in which
as usual they succeeded, I reached the vessel about 6 miles below Gravesend, between 5 and 6 o’clock. We proceeded down the river as low as Sheerness, and then for reasons best known to the Captain, came to anchor for the night, before 9.

29. At about 6 this morning we got again under weigh proceeding down the Thames the banks of which are very beautiful. We had good weather though very cold for the Season. The wind fair as it could blow. At about noon we got out of the river, and from that time had a very heavy sea rolling, which has been raised by the prevalence for several days of fresh westerly winds. I was even a little sea-sick. More so than I have before been, these ten years. At about 8 this Evening we lay to for the night. the Captain thinking himself too near the Dutch coast to proceed. This extreme caution in the night at a season, when there is not four hours of darkness at a Time is unknown to American Seamen, with one of whom our passage would by this night have been completed.

30. The weather this morning was thick drizly and cold— At about 8. land was made, being the island of Schouwen. at 9 we received a Pilot on board and about 10 made out to reach the lower harbour of the Briel, where we came to Anchor, both wind and tide being then adverse to our proceeding onwards to Rotterdam. From that time till night we had a most furious storm, so that our Captain more than once expressed his satisfaction at having reached the harbour just as we did. I contrived to pass the time with as little tediousness as the situation would allow; but I should have little relish for imprisonment.

31. Early this morning we got under weigh again, and in two or three hours beat up as high as the Briel where we changed our Pilot for another. But the tide soon turning and the wind being unfavourable we came to anchor again; from ten till about 2 we lay below just above the Briel; & the wind then coming round we sailed once more and landed at the wharf at Rotterdam just at 5. I left Whitcomb behind to bring forward the baggage, and immediately proceeded to the boat for Delft of 6 o’clock. Soon after I entered it I was joined by Mr: Bourne much to our mutual surprize at this accidental meeting. He is returning from Paris, where he has been about a month. At Delft we took a carriage, and arrived at the Hague at my old lodgings at 9 in the Evening, where I was happy to find my brother in good health. Baron Schubart whom I met at the house where we took the Carriage at Delft had already told me he was well. Mr: Bourne sat with us an hour, and though I have been several nights almost entirely deprived of rest, I kept my brother up, chatting upon various subjects till after one in the morning.
